Award.AwardTitle: Pou4 Function in an Invertebrate Chordate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Transcription factors (TF) are proteins that control the expression of genes. This project uses a simple animal that is closely related to vertebrates like ourselves, the ascidian, to study a TF called Pou4 that is important for the development of sensory neurons, which include the hair cells of the inner ear. It was previously found that expressing ascidian Pou4 in ascidian cell types where it is not usually found converts those cells into sensory neurons. Likewise, forced expression of any of the three mouse Pou4 genes in the wrong ascidian cell types also converts those cells into sensory neurons. However, in mice, expressing Pou4 in the wrong cell type does not convert those cells into sensory neurons. The present project examines the mechanistic basis for the differences between the ascidian and mouse Pou4 genes in order to better understand evolutionary changes in development that give rise to new cell types like vertebrate sensory neurons. To answer these questions, the researchers are adapting a new gene editing system (CRISPR/Cas9) to the ascidian to decipher the mechanisms behind Pou4 function. Broader Impacts: San Diego State University ranks among the top US universities for economic and campus ethnic diversity. The proposed study will provide laboratory research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. To broaden the overall understanding of the function and experimental use of transgenic organisms to SDSU's larger undergraduate population, the researchers are working with the coordinator of their introductory cell and molecular biology courses to develop a relatively simple, "hands on" exercise where students can generate and assay transgenic ascidian embryos.

In ascidians, the single Pou4 (CiPou4) transcription factor (TF) is a key regular of the PNS, and ectopic expression of this gene produces ectopic sensory neurons. In mammals, there are three Pou4s; all predominately expressed in sensory neurons. The investigators used RNA-SEQ to identify CiPou4 transcriptional targets and many are known to be expressed in vertebrate hair cells, suggesting a deep evolutionary linkage between these cells types. In mammals, ectopic expression of the hair cell Pou4F3 gene does not produce new hair cells; but when expressed in ascidians ectopic sensory neurons are generated. This observation suggests that while protein function is conserved, Pou4 transcriptional targets have been lost and/or are differentially regulated in vertebrates. Here we will use RNA-SEQ to determine if the mouse Pou4 TFs activate similar transcriptional targets compared to CiPou4. We will test if a CRISPR/Cas9-mediated CiPou4 knock-out can be rescued by the mouse Pou4 genes. This project is transformative because the ascidian larva provides a unique system to examine the evolution of TF function and the role this TF has played during the evolution of a novel vertebrate cell type, the sensory hair cell.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our laboratory uses the ascidian embryo, an invertebrate animal closely related to ourselves, to understand how the sensory neurons of the peripheral nervous system are formed. In ascidian tadpole larvae, these cells are found along the midlines of the tail and are called epidermal sensory neurons. They share many features in common with the hair cells of vertebrates that are found in the inner ear where they function to help maintain balance and mediate hearing. In previous NSF-funded research, we discovered that a key transcription factor, a gene that can control the expression of other genes, called Pou4 can produce extra sensory neurons when misexpressed in the epidermis of the larva. Interestingly, all three variants of Pou4 from the mouse (Pou4F1, Pou4F2 and Pou4F3) produce extra sensory cells in ascidians when misexpressed, but none of the variants when misexpressed in mice have the capacity to produce extra sensory neurons. This award provided funding to explore the discrepancy in the function in these genes.

 

Intellectual Merit: Embryos misexpressing Pou4 in their epidermal cells convert those cells to sensory neurons. To identify the genes important for this conversion, we compared the genes expressed in normal larvae to larvae misexpressing Pou4 in the epidermis (Aim 1 of the proposal). Using high throughput RNA sequencing approaches and bioinformatics, we discovered that many of the genes expressed in the sensory neurons are also expressed in vertebrate hair cells, suggesting that these two cells types share similar structural and functional features. To determine if the mouse Pou4 genes regulate the same set of genes in ascidians as they do in the mouse, we used a similar strategy to identify the genes regulated by the mouse Pou4 genes when misexpressed in the ascidian epidermis. To our surprise, there was little overlap in the gene sets regulated by each of the four Pou4 genes, despite the fact that all of these genes are capable of producing sensory neurons when expressed in the ascidian larval epidermis. To further explore these differences, we used the CRIPSR-Cas9 system, whose discoverers were recently awarded the Nobel Prize, to reduce the function of the ascidian Pou4 protein; this resulted in the reduction of sensory neurons in the tail. We then expressed each of the four Pou4 genes (one from ascidians and three from the mouse) in presumptive sensory neurons and found that all could rescue the mutant phenotype but with differing degrees of efficiency: ascidian Pou4 worked the best followed by Pou4F3, Pou4F2 and Pou4F1 (Aim 2 of the proposal). These results suggest that while the four genes can function to produce sensory neurons, cellular context is important: the mouse Pou4 genes could all rescue sensory neurons when expressed in the proper cell type, but were less able, compared to ascidian Pou4, to produce ectopic sensory neurons. These results provide insight into how gene function has evolved over time within the chordate lineage and imply that Pou4 function has diverged since ascidians and vertebrates separated several hundred million years ago.

 

Broader Impacts: San Diego State University (SDSU) ranks among the top US universities for economic and campus ethnic diversity and has been designated a Hispanic Serving Institution. This research provided opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to study gene regulatory mechanisms combining skills from multiple disciplines including high-resolution in vivo imaging, molecular biology and bioinformatics. These approaches will demonstrate to students early in their careers the importance of interplay between various disciplines and how interactions between specialists in these fields lead to the ability to address important scientific questions. This proposal funded research projects for 10 undergraduates at SDSU, two of which defended undergraduate honors research thesis projects. This proposal funded the research of two MS students and one PhD student. Lastly, the experimental approaches used throughout this proposal were introduced to nearly 100 graduate students and postdoctoral fellows that took the Embryology Course at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA during the funding period.
